thread.title: College football Blake O’Neill death threats: punt video, Aussie’s 80-yard punt, last-minute fumble
thread.title_full: College football Blake O’Neill death threats: punt video, Aussie’s 80-yard punt, last-minute fumble

author: Liam FitzGibbon
title: College football Blake O’Neill death threats: punt video, Aussie’s 80-yard punt, last-minute fumble
text:
Video Image Aussie punter's hero to zero game 1:05 NFL: Michigan punter Blake O?Neill has had a roller-coaster game; he produced the longest punt of the season so far with this 80-yarder, but then he cost his side the game.
October 18th 2015 3 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/More Sports/ Blake O'Neill punts the ball during against the Michigan State Spartans.
Liam FitzGibbon FOX SPORTS MICHIGAN have rallied around their Australian punter Blake O’Neill after he was subjected to some vile abuse on social media after costing his side a win in college football.
O’Neill, a former Aussie rules player from Melbourne, dropped a punt with 10 seconds remaining to allow rivals Michigan State to recover the ball for a touchdown and a win 27-23 in a crazy finish on Saturday .
It was a cruel ending to the game for O’Neill who up until then had punted superbly, including an astonishing 80-yard effort in the first half.
Blake O'Neill punts the ball during the first quarter against the Michigan State Spartans. Source: AFP
However a small group of fans took to twitter to abuse O’Neill after the game, with the punter reportedly receiving death threats and messages telling him to kill himself or “go back to Australia”.
Michigan athletic director Jim Hackett today strongly condemned those fans in an open letter.
“Today I awake to the shocking reality that our community who care so much about this program would send hurtful, spiteful and vicious comments to one of our students,” Hackett said.
“To be clear, such comments come from a small minority, none of whom are reflective of our institution.”
Letter from Jim Hackett to Michigan fans after Saturday's game: pic.twitter.com/wv71K5FqUi
— Max Cohen (@MaxACohen) October 18, 2015 The promising O’Neill, a former fashion model in his senior college year, also received strong encouragement on twitter, with former and current NFL players and respected pundits reaching out.
Current Detroit Lions NFL punter Sam Martin was among those to offer support.
@blakewoneill ignore the Twitter clowns brother. Keep your head up and carry on. You're a beast, season is young my friend. 👊
— Sam (@SamMartin_6) October 18, 2015 Keep your head up young man @blakewoneill
— Jason Pinkston (@JasonPinkstonOL) October 18, 2015 I'm still sick to my stomach for that punter...Blake O'Neill wasn't trying to fail...hoping people have a bit of compassion for him
— Joel Klatt (@joelklatt) October 17, 2015 Hate tweets sent to Blake O'Neill are a disgrace. Ignore them Blake! @blakewoneill True M fans know you are a star. Mistakes happen. @GoBlue
— Gene Sperling (@genebsperling) October 18, 2015 If you are harassing the Michigan punter, be aware it says a lot more about you than it does him. He gave his best, while you are a lowlife.
— Mike Greenberg (@Espngreeny) October 18, 2015 Stay 💪 @blakewoneill failure can lead to your greatest accomplishment It eliminates fear of failure & allows u to reach your true potential
— Jay Feely (@jayfeely) October 18, 2015 O’Neill’s former development coach, ProKick Australia’s Nathan Chapman, backed the punter to bounce back strongly.
“It is not nice for young blokes to have unpleasant things said about them on the Internet,” Chamman told USA Today.
“But all he is going to care about is that he wants to go out there and do the best for his team. Saturday was a rough day for him on a big occasion, but he’s got to take it on the chin and come back stronger.”
Michigan next face Minnesota on Sunday.
Originally published as Support for Aussie punter after death threats
